title: Someone Interrupts You in a Meeting
situation: You are explaining a point in a team meeting when a colleague cuts you off and starts talking over you.
question: How do you respond in the moment?

choices.label: Let them finish, stay silent, and never return to your point.
choices.outcome: The meeting moves on without your idea being fully heard. You feel overlooked and slightly resentful.
choices.insight: Avoiding conflict can keep the peace short term, but it reinforces a pattern where your contributions are easy to ignore.

choices.label: Politely but firmly say, “I’d like to finish my thought, then I’m happy to hear your view.”
choices.outcome: The room pauses, your colleague pulls back, and you finish your point. You feel a bit nervous but also proud of yourself.
choices.insight: Calm boundary-setting signals that your voice matters without attacking the other person.

choices.label: Raise your voice and say, “Stop interrupting me, you always do this!”
choices.outcome: The room goes awkwardly quiet. Your colleague becomes defensive and the conversation derails into tension, not ideas.
choices.insight: Calling out a pattern in the heat of the moment often triggers defensiveness instead of change. Specific, calm requests work better.

title: A Friend Cancels Last Minute
situation: A close friend cancels a plan 10 minutes before you are supposed to meet. This happens often.
question: What do you do?

choices.label: Reply, “No worries!” even though you’re upset, and say nothing about the pattern.
choices.outcome: You spare them discomfort, but you stay frustrated and feel less excited to see them next time.
choices.insight: Protecting someone from your true feelings can slowly damage the relationship because resentment builds silently.

choices.label: Message, “I feel disappointed. This has happened a few times and it makes it hard for me to rely on our plans.”
choices.outcome: Your friend is surprised but appreciative of your honesty. They apologize and suggest talking about how to make plans that work better.
choices.insight: Naming how a pattern affects you focuses on impact, not blame, and opens the door to renegotiating the relationship.

choices.label: Ignore their message for days to ‘teach them a lesson.’
choices.outcome: They feel confused and anxious. The distance between you grows, but the real issue stays unspoken.
choices.insight: Withdrawing as punishment creates uncertainty, not understanding. Clarity usually works better than silent tests.

title: Your Boss Gives Vague Criticism
situation: Your boss says, “Your last report just wasn’t strong enough,” but doesn’t give any specifics.
question: How do you respond?

choices.label: Nod and say, “Okay, I’ll do better,” without asking for details.
choices.outcome: You leave the conversation unsure what to change. The next report might repeat the same mistakes.
choices.insight: Accepting vague criticism without clarity makes improvement a guessing game instead of a process.

choices.label: Say, “Could you share one or two specific things I can improve next time?”
choices.outcome: Your boss points out structure and clarity issues. You take notes and know exactly what to do differently next time.
choices.insight: Asking for concrete examples turns criticism into actionable guidance and shows you’re committed to growing.

choices.label: Defend your work by listing everything you did well and why the feedback is unfair.
choices.outcome: Your boss becomes less open and wraps up quickly. The relationship feels slightly strained.
choices.insight: Getting defensive can protect your ego short term but often closes the door on useful information.

title: A Partner Raises Their Voice
situation: During an argument about finances, your partner starts speaking loudly and sharply. You feel tense and flooded.
question: What do you do in that moment?

choices.label: Match their volume and intensity so you won’t be ‘walked over.’
choices.outcome: The argument quickly escalates. Both of you say things you regret.
choices.insight: Matching intensity can feel powerful but often pushes the conflict to a point where repair becomes harder.

choices.label: Say calmly, “I want to talk about this, but the volume is making it hard for me to think. Can we lower our voices or take a short break?”
choices.outcome: Your partner pauses. They may not fully calm down immediately, but the tone softens and there’s more space to think.
choices.insight: Naming your need without attacking the other person can shift the emotional temperature of a conversation.

choices.label: Shut down, stop talking, and mentally leave the conversation.
choices.outcome: The conflict appears to end, but the issue stays unresolved, and your partner feels shut out.
choices.insight: Checking out may protect you emotionally in the moment, but it keeps the problem alive beneath the surface.

title: A Team Member Misses a Deadline
situation: A colleague repeatedly turns in their part of a shared project late, making you rush your own work.
question: How do you bring it up?

choices.label: Do their part quietly yourself so the project doesn’t suffer.
choices.outcome: The project looks fine, but your workload is unsustainable, and the pattern continues.
choices.insight: Taking on extra work can save a project in the short term but often teaches others that deadlines don’t matter.

choices.label: Say, “When your part arrives late, I end up rushing. Can we agree on a specific time that works for you so I can plan my work realistically?”
choices.outcome: Your colleague understands the impact on you and proposes a more realistic interim deadline.
choices.insight: Describing consequences and inviting collaboration helps shift behavior without attacking character.

choices.label: Complain about them to the manager without speaking to them first.
choices.outcome: Your colleague feels blindsided when the manager brings it up, and trust between you drops.
choices.insight: Going around someone can resolve the issue temporarily but often damages direct working relationships.

title: You Receive an Overly Personal Joke
situation: In a group, someone makes a joke about your appearance that feels too personal. Others laugh.
question: What do you do?

choices.label: Fake laugh along so you don’t look sensitive.
choices.outcome: The moment passes, but you feel smaller and less safe around that person.
choices.insight: Laughing off discomfort can train others to cross your lines without realizing it.

choices.label: Smile slightly and say, “Hey, not cool. Jokes about my appearance are off-limits.”
choices.outcome: The group quiets for a moment. The person looks a bit embarrassed but backs off.
choices.insight: Short, clear boundary statements can reset what’s acceptable without turning it into a lecture.

choices.label: Snap back with an even harsher joke about them.
choices.outcome: The group laughs again, but the atmosphere shifts from playful to edgy. The other person may start seeing you as an adversary.
choices.insight: Meeting hurtful humor with more hurt can feel satisfying but often escalates tension instead of correcting it.

title: A Client Keeps Expanding the Scope
situation: A freelance client keeps asking for small ‘quick' additions that weren’t in the original agreement.
question: How do you respond to the latest request?

choices.label: Say yes again because you don’t want to seem difficult.
choices.outcome: The project grows bigger while your fee stays the same, and you feel increasingly undervalued.
choices.insight: Saying yes to every extra request trains clients to expect free work by default.

choices.label: Reply, “That’s beyond our agreed scope. I can absolutely add it for an additional X, or we can save it for a future phase.”
choices.outcome: The client may hesitate but respects the clarity. Some will accept the fee; others will prioritize.
choices.insight: Naming scope and offering options respects both your boundaries and the client’s goals.

choices.label: Ignore the request and hope they forget about it.
choices.outcome: The client follows up, now slightly irritated. Trust in your reliability decreases.
choices.insight: Avoidance rarely makes business issues disappear; it usually just delays an uncomfortable conversation.

title: You Want a Quiet Night, They Want to Go Out
situation: You’ve had a long day and want a quiet night in. Your partner is excited to go out and socialize.
question: How do you handle the mismatch?

choices.label: Force yourself to go out so they won’t be disappointed.
choices.outcome: You feel drained and a bit irritable all evening, which affects how much you both enjoy the night.
choices.insight: Consistently overriding your own needs can lead to burnout and hidden resentment.

choices.label: Say, “I really need a quiet night. Could we do something low-key, or would you like to go out with friends while I recharge?”
choices.outcome: You find a compromise: a short outing or separate plans. Both needs are acknowledged.
choices.insight: Treating both people’s needs as valid makes it easier to negotiate instead of ‘win’ a situation.

choices.label: Say, “You’re so selfish, you never think about how tired I am,” and shut the conversation down.
choices.outcome: Your partner feels attacked, not understood. The conversation becomes about character, not plans.
choices.insight: Global labels (“you always…”) often lead to defensiveness, not cooperation.

title: You Need Help But Don’t Want to Bother Anyone
situation: You are stuck on a task and behind on time but worry you’ll look incompetent if you ask for help.
question: What do you do?

choices.label: Keep struggling alone, even though you’re making little progress.
choices.outcome: The deadline gets closer and your stress increases. The final result may suffer.
choices.insight: Protecting your image can sometimes cost you the support that would actually improve your performance.

choices.label: Ask a colleague, “Do you have 10 minutes? I’m stuck on this part and a second pair of eyes would help.”
choices.outcome: They clarify the sticking point quickly. You feel relieved and finish more confidently.
choices.insight: Specific, time-bound requests are easier for others to say yes to and show that you respect their time.

choices.label: Complain loudly about how hard everything is so someone will eventually offer help.
choices.outcome: People may step in, but some see you as negative or dramatic rather than collaborative.
choices.insight: Indirect bids for help can work but often blur the line between venting and problem-solving.

title: You Disagree With a Friend’s Opinion Online
situation: A friend posts an opinion you strongly disagree with on social media. You feel tempted to argue in the comments.
question: How do you respond?

choices.label: Write a long public comment picking apart their argument point by point.
choices.outcome: The conversation quickly becomes performative and tense. You both feel less close afterward.
choices.insight: Public debates with friends often prioritize being right over staying connected.

choices.label: Send a private message: “I see this differently and would love to understand your view better if you’re open to it.”
choices.outcome: You have a slower, more thoughtful exchange in private. You may still disagree, but you both feel heard.
choices.insight: Moving sensitive conversations out of the spotlight makes it easier to stay curious instead of combative.

choices.label: Silently mute them and never mention it.
choices.outcome: Your feed becomes calmer, but they have no idea why you pulled away, and the distance grows invisibly.
choices.insight: Sometimes protecting your space is healthy, but avoiding all hard conversations can slowly hollow out relationships.
